INTRODUCTION
The Dogwood Energy Facility is committed to protecting the public, its employees, and the environment in accordance with the highest regulatory and ethical standards.  As part of that commitment, we have implemented safety, environmental protection, and risk management programs to prevent any accidental releases of hazardous materials.

The Dogwood Energy Facility (Plant) maintains one substance, anhydrous ammonia, on site in amounts exceeding the RMP rule threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds. The Plant stores anhydrous ammonia in an 18,190 gallon storage tank with administrative controls limiting the tank level to 80% capacity (i.e. 75,670 pounds). 

Anhydrous ammonia is used as an air pollution control system additive, to minimize the formation of nitrogen oxides in combustion turbine flue gas emissions. The Plant is a combined cycle electric generating plant, consisting of two combustion turbines with heat recovery system and a common steam turbine generator. Each combustion turbine is equipped with a selective catalytic reduction (SCR) system. Part of the SCR system is the anhydrous ammonia tank, piping and associated equipment which are addressed in this Risk Management Plan. 

The Plant is also subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (codified in 29 CFR 1910.119) because it stores greater than 10,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. As such, the facility is required to have a PSM program, which is essentially equivalent to the RMP prevention program. 

PLANT DESCRIPTION The Plant is located in Cass County, Missouri, at 25111 E. 175th Street, Pleasant Hill. The facility is located approximately 1.5-miles west of downtown Pleasant Hill and 1-mile east of the intersection of State Highway BB and E. 175th Street. The property immediately surrounding the power plant is unimproved or used for agricultural purposes. The topography is generally hilly with small pockets of woodlands along fence rows and hollows. 

AMMONIA SYSTEM DESCRIPTION

The ammonia unloading and storage system is composed of four (4) major components: a tanker truck unloading station, ammonia storage tank, ammonia vaporization skid, and SCR equipment. The tanker truck unloading station is designed to provide a safe means of linking the ammonia delivery truck to the storage tank for the transfer of ammonia. One 18,190-gallon horizontal tank is provided for anhydrous ammonia storage. The tank is situated in a concrete dike. In the event that the ambient temperature outside the tank falls below a temperature that will generate enough heat to provide the required ammonia flow rate the SCR system requires, an ammonia vaporizer skid provides additional heating to keep an adequate vapor supply from the storage tank. Ammonia vapors drawn from the tank are regulated for pressure, mixed with air, and injected into the combustion turbine flue gases within each respective ammonia injection grid. In combination with the catalyst in the SCR unit, nitrogen oxides are reacted and emissions of the pollutant are reduced. 

WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO 
The worst case release scenario for ammonia was identified as the loss of the contents of the entire 18,190-gallon tank as a gas in accordance with the definition provided in the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) guidance for RMP development. As allowed in 40 CFR Part 68.25 (b)(1) of the RMP rule, the administratively controlled maximum tank level of 80% liquid by volume was taken into consideration in the evaluation of this release. The conditions of the scenario, such as release time and weather status are those specified in the EPA Off-Site Consequence Analysis Guidance. The distance of potential impact was determined using RMP*Comp modeling software provided by EPA. This distance and a list of the types of receptors in a circle constituting the potential impact area are provided to EPA elsewhere in the RMP submittal. In the event of a release, it is expected that an ammonia plume would disper

se in the direction of the prevailing wind at the time of the event and not encompass the entire circle used to identify potential impacts.

This type of rapid release would occur only if the ammonia tank were breached. The likelihood of such an incident occurring is extremely low. EPA release reporting databases and industry experience suggest that the worst-case release scenario as defined in the RMP regulations is so unlikely that it should not be used as the basis for emergency planning.  A more reasonable potential release scenario for emergency planning is presented in "The alternative release scenario(s)" section below. Anhydrous ammonia tanks are installed with multiple safety systems to prevent the release of an entire tank in a single event.  

ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO 
The alternative release scenario is, by definition, a more likely release scenario than the worst case. Engineered controls, such as automatic shut-off valves, check valves, relief valves, ammonia vapor leak detection system and alarms are considered in the analysis.

The type of system failure identified for the alternative release was a loss of ammonia caused by a major leak in the liquid piping network between the storage tank and the vaporizers. As a conservative estimate, the rate of release was assumed to be the maximum flow rate that would not cause the tank liquid excess flow valves to automatically shut. The leak was assumed to continue until the sounding of the ammonia vapor detector alarm, at which time the operator would be alerted to check the ammonia system. The main isolation valve would then be closed, manually if safe to do so. If the ammonia vapor concentration proved unsafe for facility response, the Pleasant Hill Fire Department would be called to respond to the emergency. The worst case time from leak detection to complete response for the Fire Department in the alternate release scenario was estimated to be 45 minutes.  The results of the process hazard analysis (P

HA) and the facility's operating history suggest that even this credible worst-case is extremely unlikely to occur, but it can serve as the basis for emergency planning.  The distance of potential impact determined using RMP*Comp modeling software and a list of the types of receptors in the potential impact area are provided to EPA elsewhere in the RMP submittal.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION STEPS

Dogwood Energy Facility is committed to public safety, personnel safety, continued reliable operation, and regulatory compliance.  Based on this commitment, the Plant Manager has assumed overall responsibility for the development and implementation of the Risk Management Program.  The Plant staff has clearly defined accountability and responsibility for each of the prevention program elements to meet both EPA and OSHA Process Safety Management requirements.

To ensure that a worst-case or alternative release scenario does not occur, Dogwood Energy Facility maintains a release prevention program with the primary focus of protecting the public and plant employees from the hazards associated with an accident or release involving anhydrous ammonia.  The multifaceted program includes:

A?    Ammonia gas detectors and alarms to rapidly alert operators to any problems.

A?    Process Safety Information is compiled to document the safe process design.

A?    Initial and periodic process hazard analysis is conducted on the ammonia system using a Hazard and Operability Analysis (HAZOP) type safety review to evaluate chemical and process hazards associated with the system design and operation. The entire system was methodically assessed and evaluated, including compliance industry codes and standards. 

A?    The Plant has operation, maintenance and inspection procedures to ensure the anhydrous ammonia system is operated safely and maintained according to applicable standards and manufacturer's recommendations. 

A?    Training, Hot Work Permits, Contractor Safety, and Employee Participation Pro

grams are used to ensure that all employees and contractors working on and around the processes are aware of the hazards, can perform their job duties safely and know the actions to be taken in an emergency. 

A?    Management of Change and Pre-startup Safety Reviews are conducted to ensure that changes are documented, analyzed and kept within the design basis;

A?    Incident Investigation procedures are used to investigate each incident and "near miss" to determine root causes and make safety improvements when needed to prevent a reoccurrence; and,

A?    Periodic Compliance Audits are conducted to ensure that our programs are working as they should to protect both the public and employees.

A?    The ammonia tank and vaporizer skid are located outdoors within a concrete dike to contain potential spills and leaks. 

A?    A water fogging system has been provided to cool the tank and piping in the event of a fire. 

A?    The ammonia storage tank is equipped with a temperature indicator, liquid level indicator, liquid level transmitter, pressure indicator, pressure transmitter and four (4) vapor relief valves providing redundancy in the event any relief valve fails.

A?    Liquid outlets from the tank are equipped with excess flow check valves that will prevent the tank from emptying in the event of a piping breakage. 

A?    The vapor outlet from the tank to the SCR system is equipped with an excess flow check valve, and an automatic block valve that shuts the flow of ammonia vapors in the event of an ammonia leak or plant failure. 

A?    Hydrostatic relief valves are located throughout the piping network to prevent piping from being damaged when isolated and filled with liquid ammonia. 

A?    Multiple manual shut-off valves are located throughout the system to facilitate operator response in case of an incident.

A?    Unloading of ammonia from tanker trucks will be attended by the delivery driver and a Plant operator for the entire duration of each transfer. The plant operator will be wearing

the proper PPE during the transfer. The unloading station consists of a liquid fill line and vapor return line between the storage tank and tanker truck to properly equalize pressure during unloading. Both lines are equipped with quick disconnect fittings and check valves that allow a safe disconnect in the event the truck pulls away from the unloading station prematurely. Both lines are equipped with emergency shutoff valves that will allow the operator to manually stop the flow of ammonia. Each emergency shutoff valve has a remote cable so that they can be operated at a safe distance from the truck. The station is equipped with a level indicator that displays the level of fluid in the storage tank to prevent overfilling. 

EMERGENCY ACTION PLAN In the event that a release does occur, the Plant's Emergency Action Plan addresses ammonia incident response. Plant personnel are trained to respond to leaks that can be managed by shutting off key emergency valves. The Pleasant Hill Fire Department will provided trained personnel to perform any response requiring entry into a dangerous atmosphere or situation. 

ACCIDENT HISTORY The Plant has not had any ammonia releases in its history that resulted in injuries or property damage. The plant has maintained an excellent safety record throughout its operating history and has never had a major anhydrous ammonia release that could have had adverse effects on the public.
